title: Forgiveness & Letting Go
description: Explore how you move past hurts and conflicts

questions.text: When my partner apologizes sincerely, I can let go of the hurt.

therapeutic.rationale: Accepting apologies and releasing hurt allows relationships to move forward. Holding onto resentment after sincere repair attempts keeps couples stuck.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner struggles to let go after apologies, explore what's missing. Do the apologies feel complete? Is there a pattern that makes trusting change hard?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to accept apologies and move on creates a fresh-start dynamic.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you let go after your partner apologizes? What makes it hard?

questions.text: I sense my partner letting go after I've apologized sincerely.

therapeutic.rationale: Receiving forgiveness after sincere apology is essential for repair. When apologies don't lead to forgiveness, partners stop trying to make amends.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't receive forgiveness, explore what's happening. Are the apologies landing? Is there accumulated hurt? Understanding the barrier helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual capacity for forgiveness creates a complete repair cycle.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does your partner forgive you after you apologize? What affects that?

questions.text: We don't keep score of past wrongs.

therapeutic.rationale: Score-keeping creates a tit-for-tat dynamic that poisons relationships. Letting go of the ledger allows each situation to be addressed on its own merits.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner keeps score, explore what the score-keeping is trying to communicate. Often it signals accumulated hurt or unfairness that needs attention.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared commitment to not keeping score frees you from the past.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Is there a mental ledger in your relationship? What would help let it go?

questions.text: Once we've worked through something, it truly feels resolved.

therapeutic.rationale: True resolution means issues don't keep resurfacing. When conflicts feel genuinely resolved, couples can move forward without dragging the past.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If issues keep returning, they may not have been fully resolved. What was missed in the original conversation? Sometimes deeper needs were unaddressed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared experience of genuine resolution creates trust in your repair process.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do resolved conflicts stay resolved? What makes some issues keep returning?

questions.text: I believe my partner wants to grow from our conflicts, not just move past them.

therapeutic.rationale: Growing from conflict rather than just surviving it creates learning. Believing your partner wants to grow builds trust that patterns will actually change.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't sense growth orientation, explore what creates that impression. Are apologies followed by change? Does reflection happen?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual commitment to growing from conflict creates an improving relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do your conflicts lead to growth? What would help you learn more from them?
